newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia to launch Inmarsat satellite on Sept 6.
newsitem.headline: Russia to launch Inmarsat satellite on Sept 6.

text.p: Russia will launch a U.S.-built satellite for the international telecommunication organisation Inmarsat on Friday, a Russian space official said on Wednesday.

Sergei Zhiltsov, spokesman for the Khrunichev Space Centre which makes the Proton booster rocket, told Reuters the Inmarsat-3 probe would be launched on a four-stage Proton rocket from Russia's Baikonur cosmodrome in Kazakhstan.
Zhiltsov said the Russian military space forces would be in charge of the launch. He would not say how much it would cost.
The launch is scheduled for 9 p.m. Moscow time (1700 GMT).

"It will be the second of 20 commercial satellite launches planned by 2000 under an agreement between the Khrunichev Space Centre and the U.S.-backed joint venture International Launch Services (ILS)", he said.
In April, ILS launched the U.S.-built Astra-1F telecommunications satellite ordered by Societe Europeene des Satellites (SES). The probe was also put into orbit by Proton booster.
Friday's launch marks another step in growing cooperation in space between the two former Cold War enemies.
It includes a $190-million deal signed by the Khrunichev Space Centre and Boeing Co. in 1995 to develop and launch the first module of the ambitious new international space station, named Alpha.
Cooperation has also started in manned space flight. American astronaut Shannon Lucid is currently on board Russia's Mir orbital station with two Russian cosmonauts.

Russian insurance firms said the Proton rocket was insured for 33 billion roubles ($6.1 million). The president of Megaruss insurance company, Alexander Tsys, told Interfax news agency that more than 40 Russian firms had taken part in insuring the Proton booster from all risks during the launch.
